c74object.name: fl.makewindow~
c74object.digest: Generates a specified window function across each output frame
c74object.description: The length of the output is dependent on the mode parameter. Output length may be set by parameter or based on that of the trigger input. Gain compensation can be applied using the compensate parameter. The included endpoints are controllable so as to fit different applications.

entry.name: /mode [enum]
entry.description:
Controls how the output length is determined:
requested - the output length is set by the length parameter.
input - the output length follows the length of the trigger input.
[0] - requested [1] - input

entry.name: /length [int]
entry.description: Sets the requested output length in the units specified by the units parameter.

entry.name: /units [enum]
entry.description:
Sets the units used for the length parameter.
[0] - samples [1] - ms [2] - seconds

entry.name: /window [enum]
entry.description:
Sets the window type:
rectangle - a window of equal values.
triangle - a triangular window.
trapezoid - an adjustable trapezoid window.
welch - the Welch polynomial window.
parzen - the Parzen polynomial window.
tukey - the adjustable Tukey (or cosine-tapered) window.
sine - the sine (or cosine) window.
hann - the Hann window.
hamming - the Hamming window with a0 = 0.54 and a1 = 0.46.
blackman - the Blackman window with a0 = 0.42, a1 = 0.50, and a2 = 0.08.
exact_blackman - the exact Blackman window as outlined in the literature.
The coefficients are a0 = 7938/18608, a1 = 9240/18608 and a2 = 1430/18608.
blackman_harris - the Blackman-Harris window with 92dB rejection.
nuttall_continuous - Nuttalls continuous 1st derivative window with 93dB rejection.
nuttall_minimal - Nuttalls minimal sidelobe window with 98dB rejection.
flat_top - Heinzels flat-top window with 95dB rejection.
cosine_sum - a sum of cosines as set by the parameters.
kaiser - an kaiser window adjustable via the beta parameter.
sine_taper - one of the sine tapers selectable by parameter.
[0] - rectangle [1] - triangle [2] - trapezoid [3] - welch [4] - parzen [5] - tukey [6] - sine [7] - hann [8] - hamming [9] - blackman [10] - exact_blackman [11] - blackman_harris [12] - nuttall_continuous [13] - nuttall_minimal [14] - flat_top [15] - cosine_sum [16] - kaiser [17] - sine_taper

entry.name: /exponent [double]
entry.description: Sets an exponent that each value in the window should be raised to.

entry.name: /compensate [enum]
entry.description:
Sets the gain compensation (the window is divided by the compensated gain).
off - no compensation is used.
linear - compensate the linear gain of the window.
square - compensate the gain of the window when applied twice (squared).
reconstruct - compensate the gain of the squared window divided by the linear gain.
This last mode is suited to FFT output windows used with the same input window.
Note that the gain of the window is calculated after applying any exponent.
[0] - off [1] - linear [2] - square [3] - reconstruct

entry.name: /parameters [variable length double array]
entry.description:
An array that sets parameters specific to the window type:
trapezoid - takes either one or two parameter as percentages.
If one parameter is provided it sets the first high point which is then mirrored.
If two parameters are provided they set the two points of the trapezoid.
The defaults are 25% and 75%.
tukey - takes a single parameter to set the cosine percentage (defaults to 50%).
When set to 100% the window is the same as the Hann window.
Reducing the percentage increases the central plateau.
cosine_sum - takes up to 5 parameters (a0-a4) as in the following formula.
w(x) = a0 - a1 * cos(2πx) + a2 * cos(4πx) - a3 * cos(6πx) + a4 * cos(8πx).
The defaults are set to the values for a Hann window.
kaiser - takes a single parameter to set beta (defaults to 6.24).
sine_taper - takes a single integer parameter to select the taper (defaults to 1).
Other window types do not taken any parameters.

entry.name: /endpoints [enum]
entry.description:
Sets which endpoints of the window will be generated.
For spectral applications a periodic window (first or last) is preferable.
For granular or filter usage a symmetric window (both or none) is preferable.
[0] - both [1] - first [2] - last [3] - none

method.name: info
method.description:
Print info about fl.makewindow~ to the max window for reference purposes. If no arguments are provided then all information is posted to the Max window. Else, a set of flags is used to select which sections of the reference to display, and whether or not the information should be provided in a shortened form.
The following flags are available:
description - display the object description.inputs - display info on inputs.outputs - display info on outputs.io - display info on both inputs and outputs.parameters - display info on the object parameters.quick - display shorten versions of any info displayed.

attribute.name: rt
attribute.description:
Sets the realtime state for fl.makewindow~. When set to 0 fl.makewindow~ can form part of a non-realtime network for processing in message threads, using buffer~ objects for audio IO.
More info on non-realtime processing with FrameLib can be found in Tutorial 11.

attribute.name: id
attribute.description:
Sets the context name for fl.makewindow~.
More info on FrameLib contexts can be found in Tutorial 10.
